step1.title: Preparation & Component Check
step1.aboutText: The HermiBorÃ° is a simulation board that connects to a PLC via an IDC cable. Students solder everything themselves â€” that's the exercise! The board must be correctly soldered and tested before it goes into the box.
step1.check1: Received the PCB â€” check for cracks or damage
step1.check2: All tools ready: Soldering iron (350â€“380Â°C), solder wire, flux, cutters, tweezers
step1.check3: Good lighting at the workstation â€” use a desk lamp if available
step1.check4: Component bag ready â€” count components and compare to the table below
step1.tableCaption: List of all components needed for the HermiBorÃ°
step1.t_switch_note: On/Off vs Push â€” look carefully
step1.t_res_note: LED resistors, read the colour bands
step1.tipSort: Sort the components by type before you start â€” it saves a lot of time and prevents mistakes.

step2.title: Place Components on the PCB
step2.warnText: Solder in the correct order! Start with low-profile components (resistors, diodes) and work your way up (relays, connectors). This prevents awkward situations when you need to hold other components down.
step2.orderHeading: Soldering order â€” click to mark done
step2.polarityText:
Cathode (â€“): White/grey band on the diode body. Marked with a triangle on the board.
LED Anode (+): Longer leg = positive. If the legs are equal length, measure with a multimeter.

step3.title: Soldering
step3.safetyText: The soldering iron is 350â€“380Â°C. Never touch the tip directly. Use the holder to cool the tip and keep solder joints short â€” under 3 seconds â€” to avoid heat damage.
step3.qualityHeading: What does a good solder joint look like?
step3.q1: Shiny and smooth â€” a good joint is glossy and cone-shaped (like a small mountain)
step3.q2: No cold joints â€” they are grey and wrinkled, poor conductors
step3.q3: No bridges â€” solder between pins that should not be connected
step3.q4: Leads trimmed â€” cut leads after soldering, not too short
step3.techHeading: Soldering technique â€” step by step
step3.t1: Place the component and bend the leads slightly to hold it
step3.t2: Heat both the pin and copper pad simultaneously for 2â€“3 sec
step3.t3: Apply solder to the pin/pad junction â€” not directly to the iron
step3.t4: Remove solder first, then the iron â€” let it cool for 5 sec without moving
step3.t5: Inspect the result with a magnifying glass or phone camera
step3.t6: Trim the leads â€” hold the cutters over the lead so clippings don't fly
step3.tipFlux: Use flux if the solder doesn't flow well. Flux removes oxidation and makes soldering much easier â€” especially useful on the IDC connector.

step4.title: Visual Inspection
step4.whyText: Visual inspection prevents damage to the tester. Take your time â€” 1 minute inspecting = 10 minutes debugging.
step4.i1: All 12 LEDs â€” correct polarity, longer leg = anode
step4.i2: All 4 general diodes â€” white band at correct marking
step4.i3: All 8 flyback diodes â€” correct polarity across relay coils
step4.i4: All 4 relays â€” deep enough and straight, pins not bent
step4.i5: All 8 switches â€” secure and straight
step4.i6: IDC connector â€” all 40 pins soldered, no bridges
step4.i7: MSTB connectors â€” J2 and J3 soldered, all points checked
step4.i8: No loose leads sticking out of the board
step4.i9: No visible bridges or shorts on the back side
step4.i10: No cold joints â€” grey and wrinkled
step4.fixText: Use a solder sucker or solder wick to remove the defect. Don't try to solder over a cold joint â€” remove it first.

step5.title: Testing with the Tester
step5.aboutText: The tester connects to the IDC connector and indicates whether everything works correctly. The teacher/instructor will help with this step.
step5.c1: Check that nothing is connected to the MSTB connector J2
step5.c2: Connect the IDC cable between HermiBorÃ° and tester â€” pin 1 = pin 1
step5.c3: Connect 12V/GND to J3 â€” red = +, black = â€“
step5.c4: Turn on the tester and observe the results
step5.testHeading: Test results â€” click to record
step5.failText: Turn off the tester immediately and inspect the relevant part of the board. Most common: wrong polarity on diode/LED, cold joint, or bridge between pins.

step6.title: FabLab â€” Base Plate
step6.aboutText: FabLab is used to cut out a base plate from MDF or acrylic. It holds the PCB at an appropriate height and protects it.
step6.f1: Open Lightburn or Inkscape on the FabLab computer
step6.f2: Measure the PCB and set the cut pattern â€” hole in each corner (3 mm diameter)
step6.f3: Select appropriate material â€” 3 mm MDF or acrylic
step6.f4: Place the material on the laser cutter and secure well
step6.f5: Run the cut and inspect the result
step6.tipCustom: Add your name or VMA logo as an engraving on the plate â€” easy and looks great!

step7.title: FabLab â€” 3D Printed Feet
step7.aboutText: The feet are 3D-printed from PLA or PETG. They keep the board at a comfortable height, provide ventilation, and prevent sliding.
step7.p1: Open PrusaSlicer or Bambu Studio and load the foot model
step7.p3: Select PLA or PETG â€” PLA works fine
step7.p5: When printing is done, remove brim/skirt if needed
step7.p6: Attach the feet to the base plate and mount the PCB on top
step7.tipInserts: You can use M3 heat inserts for a stronger connection. Melt into the foot with a soldering iron at 200Â°C.
step7.doneText: When the feet are in place and the board is mounted â€” you're ready to complete the project!
